thread.title: Patch proves to be the perfect match
thread.title_full: Patch proves to be the perfect match

title: Patch proves to be the perfect match
text:
Patch proves to be the perfect match Shirley Sinclair | 13th Jul 2015 9:27 AM Shirley Sinclair Mystique with his Tin Can Bay Dolphin Centre volunteer. Shirley Sinclair Local Real Estate Cars For Sale 
SHE may be wild but she is much better mannered than my pet cattle dog when food is around. 
Patch the Dolphin has popped in with 23-year-old pod alpha male Mystique for the 8am feeding time at the Tin Can Bay Dolphin Centre at Barnacles Cafe. 
Mystique has been interacting with Tin Can Bay locals and tourists all his life as a third-generation visitor. 
Dolphins have been coming to the cafe for a free feed since the 1950s, when one - nicknamed Old Scarry - beached himself on the sand after reportedly being cut by a boat propeller. 
The locals and fishermen felt sorry for him and started to feed him as he convalesced in the area. 
Old Scarry eventually returned to the wild but regularly came back to visit and enjoy more easy treats. 
A second dolphin nicknamed Scarry also began visiting and arrived in the bay in 1991, with her calf Mystique. 
Scarry has not been seen since 2004, and, for a time, Mystique also took a break from the dolphin centre but returned after a couple of months with Patch, now his 20-something friend. 
A younger member of his pod, Harmony, has also been appearing in recent times to become a fourth-generation visitor. Photos View Photo Gallery 
The dolphins, which change in colour according to age from grey to cream or pink, grow to more than 2.5m in length, with long beaks and mounded forehead. 
Fatty tissue in their backs, that increases with age, and their elongated dorsal fin give them the humpback appearance. 
Mystique and Patch's calm nature already has won over the 100-strong school-holiday crowd when our two-day Fraser Island tour group arrives in The Discovery Group "Warrior" 4WD vehicle. 
Today's pair wait patiently beside the two female volunteers standing in the water as we are educated about Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin behaviour and the do's and don'ts around them (no mobile phones and no flash photography, especially). 
While many stand above the beach for a bird's-eye view, some of us have moved in for a closer look, knee-deep in the water in front of these charmingly beautiful marine creatures. 
Cormorants and huge pelicans try to steal the show (and any fish nearby) every chance they get, before being shoo-ed away by other eagle-eyed volunteers. 
Then the beach is cleared and those with a $5 blue feeding pass wait orderly in line near the kiosk to wash their hands with antibacterial water before receiving their single fish in a bucket. 
I am among the last in line, having spent a good 15 minutes snapping others enjoying this unique experience. 
Finally, it's my turn and I'm directed to Christine in the yellow sprayjacket and Patch. 
Christine urges me closer and closer towards Patch until I am only centimetres away from her long closed beak. I follow instructions to take the fish out and hold it still under the water. 
Patch moves forward slowly and, ever so gently and politely, accepts the morsel offered - just like a high-society lady at a high tea would pick up a petit four from a silver platter. 
I'm sure that for the briefest of moments, we make eye contact. 
And while the dolphin-to-human encounter may not have left a lasting impression on Patch, she has certainly left one on me. 
*The writer won The Discover Group two-day Fraser Island experience as a quiz prize. 
DOLPHINS AHOY 
TIN Can Bay Wild Dolphin Centre is at Barnacles Café at Norman Point, overlooking Snapper Creek - just over 90minutes drive from Noosa. 
Entry fee is $5 per person, plus $5 for each fish. Proceeds cover fish purchases and other costs. 
The dolphins arrive between 7-8am daily and the feeding starts at 8am. Noosaville's The Discovery Group visits the Tin Can Bay Wild Dolphin Centre as part of its two-day Fraser Island Experience. 
Visit www.thediscoverygroup. com.au or phone 54490393. dolphins
